title: 115_s1503
content: The Act may be cited as the "Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame Commemorative Coin Act". The Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame was founded in 1959 in Springfield, Massachusetts to honor the creator of basketball, Dr. James Naismith. It recognizes players, coaches, referees, and other contributors to the sport. The Inaugural Hall of Fame Class of 1959 included 17 honorees, including Dr. Naismith. The Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame, founded in 1959 in Springfield, Massachusetts, honors basketball legends like Dr. James Naismith, George Mikan, Forrest C. Allen, and others. It is renowned worldwide for preserving basketball history and celebrating the achievements of players, coaches, and contributors. The Hall of Fame offers educational programs promoting positive values demonstrated by basketball icons. Basketball is considered a national treasure in the United States for its fast-paced nature reflecting freedom. The Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame, established in 1959 in Springfield, Massachusetts, is home to the largest collection of basketball memorabilia globally, attracting over 6 million visitors interested in the game's rich history. It reaches over 7 million Americans through educational programs, events, exhibits, and its interactive website. The Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame offers customized educational programs using basketball to teach important lessons on various topics like financial literacy, mathematics, civil rights, leadership, history, and geography. They will lead the celebration of basketball's 60th anniversary and partner with organizations like the NBA, NCAA, and USA Basketball during the 2019-2020 season. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $5 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half-dollar clad coins with specific weights, diameters, and metal compositions. The coins minted under this Act will have a diameter of 1.205 inches, minted to half-dollar specifications, legal tender, considered numismatic items, and in the shape of a dome. The design of coins under this Act will be in the shape of a dome. The design for coins minted under this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. Each coin will have a value designation, the year "2019" inscribed, and words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The Secretary will hold a competition to determine the design of the common obverse of the coins, emblematic of basketball. The Secretary will determine the design of coins minted under this Act through a selection process involving artists, engravers, and the general public. The winning design will receive compensation of at least $5,000, which will influence the sale price. The common reverse design of the coins will also be decided. The design on the common reverse of the coins minted under this Act will depict a basketball. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2019. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges: $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $5 for the half-dollar coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame to fund operations and educational programming. The Hall of Fame will be audited for the amounts received. No surcharge may exceed the specified amounts. (d) Limitation.--No surcharge may be included for any coin issued under this Act in a calendar year if it would exceed the annual commemorative coin program issuance limitation. The Secretary of the Treasury can provide guidance on this.
